Award.AwardTitle: Metal Coordination Compounds as Reporters for Biological NO, HNO, and S-Nitrosothiols
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Stephen J. Lippard of the Department of Chemistry at Massachusetts Institute of Technology explores transition metal-mediated reactions of nitric oxide (NO), nitroxyl (HNO), and S-nitrosothiols, three distinct but chemically related biological signaling agents. The project elucidates physiological and pathological actions of NO and HNO, with impacts on chemistry, biology, neuroscience, and medicine. The Lippard group actively supports gender and ethnic diversity, as well as the mentoring and training of underrepresented minorities in science at undergraduate, graduate, and postgraduate levels. Professor Lippard participates in workshops and lectures that instill excitement for bioinorganic chemistry.

Metal coordination chemistry is central to many of the transformations involved in the biological synthesis and signal transduction of NO. The research investigates and exploits the underlying mechanisms of these actions in order to unravel the cellular crosstalk between NO and its derivatives HNO and S-nitrosothiols. Specifically, three directions are pursued. First, the chemistry of NO and HNO with synthetic metal derivatives of macrocyclic and tripodal ligands are utilized to inform the design of next generation fluorescent probes. At the same time, the putative interconversion of NO and HNO in biology is investigated with biomimetic models of copper-zinc (Cu-Zn) superoxide dismutase. Second, metal-based fluorescent sensors for NO and HNO are made ratiometric, reversible, rapid, and near-IR-emitting. These features enable analyte quantitation, dynamic monitoring of signaling events, response rates on the physiological time scale, and deeper tissue imaging, respectively. Third, Cu(II)- or Zn(II)-promoted transnitrosation reactions are explored with the aim of obtaining the first fluorescent sensor for direct detection of S-nitrosothiols in biological media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report: National Science Foundation Grant CHE-1565649

 

Metal Coordination Compounds as Reporters for Biological NO, HNO, and S-Nitrosothiols

 

by Stephen J. Lippard

 

Department of Chemistry, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139

 

Nitric oxide (NO) is a gaseous signaling agent that regulates processes in the human circulatory, immune, and nervous systems. Nitroxyl (HNO), the reduced and protonated form of NO, is being established as a species endowed with unique biochemical properties. How and if HNO is generated in the body are two important scientific questions still under investigation. Distinguishing NO from HNO is therefore critical for elucidating the biological functions of these two distinct messengers. Furthermore, S-nitrosation is a post-translational modification of proteins, the physiological functions of which are only beginning to be understood. To unravel the complex interplay between NO, HNO, thiols, and S-nitrosothiols in biology, molecular reporters able to discriminate them in aqueous milieu are urgently needed.

 

Transition metal ions mediate many of the pathways by which NO and HNO are produced and exert their actions in biology. This project addresses the scientific needs identified above by exploring transition metal-mediated chemistry directed toward several specific aims: (1) to prepare metal complexes that react rapidly and selectively with NO, HNO, and S-nitrosothiols; (2) to obtain improved transition metal-based fluorescent sensors for NO and HNO; (3) to develop the first metal-based fluorescent probes for selective detection of S-nitrosothiols in aqueous media, and (4) to apply these molecules in biological systems to study the generation and distribution of analytes. To enable deeper tissue penetration and high spatiotemporal resolution for biological imaging, we investigated new fluorescent and metal-binding moieties that make the sensors brighter, faster, redder, ratiometric, and more selective. An important outcome of our research is the application of solid-phase approaches to functionalize and program sensors with minimal synthetic effort. The modular solid-phase methodology developed under this project can be employed to generate families of fluorescent probes. Breakthrough results of the research conducted in the current grant period include: (a) achieving reversible sensing of nitroxyl in water with a Cu(II)-based azathiamacrocyclic model, (b) obtaining the first water-soluble constructs offering a direct-sensing alternative to indirect ratiometric NO sensors, and (c) designing and implementing the first metal-based probe for direct biological detection of S-nitrosothiols.

 

Science revealed by our Cu(II)-based sensors formulated answers to important biological questions and sparked several national and international collaborations. The prior successful implementation of our lysine-based HNO sensor CuCLT confirmed for the first time in cells a proposed biosynthetic pathway to HNO. Our improved NO sensors Cu2FL2E and Cu2FL2 were used to investigate neural regeneration following optic nerve crush. Finally, our cell-impermeable probe CuFL1A was used to assess relative NO levels in cell culture media, leading to the introduction of a first-in-class polymersome-based therapeutic construct. Several of the probes discovered as a result of previous research on this project have been made commercially available.

 

This project significantly contributed toward unveiling physiological and pathological actions of NO and HNO, with broad impacts on chemistry, biology, neuroscience, and medicine. Our research group displays gender and ethnic diversity and actively supports mentoring and training of underrepresented minorities in science at undergraduate, graduate, and postgraduate levels. Outreach activities funded by this project include international workshops, lectures, and seminars that instill passion for chemistry. The PI has been a guest on the NPR program Science Friday and has repeatedly met with the general public to disseminate the principles of bioinorganic chemistry. The future goals that he articulated for chemistry continue to serve as the basis for several academic and industrial programs.
